items.q: Which of these sports does NOT traditionally use a ball?
items.explanation: Ice hockey uses a hard, flat rubber disc called a puck.

items.q: A 'hole-in-one' in golf means the player got the ball into the hole on their very first stroke.
items.explanation: It is also known as an 'ace' and is incredibly rare to achieve.

items.q: In soccer, only the goalkeeper is allowed to intentionally touch the ball with their hands or arms during open play.
items.explanation: If any other player does it, it's considered a handball foul.

items.q: What shape is a standard rugby ball?
items.explanation: Its shape makes it easier to carry and pass backward, but challenging to kick predictably.

items.q: In which sport would you try to 'pin' your opponent's shoulders to the mat?
items.explanation: A pin immediately ends the match and awards the victory.

items.q: What is the name of the prestigious global soccer tournament held every four years?
items.explanation: It is the most widely viewed and followed single sporting event in the world.

items.q: How many players are on the court for a single volleyball team?
items.explanation: Teams rotate positions clockwise every time they win the serve back from the opposing team.

items.q: Which popular winter sport involves sliding down snow-covered hills on a single wide board attached to your feet?
items.explanation: Both feet are strapped to a single board, visually similar to skateboarding or surfing, but on snow.

items.q: What aquatic sport involves racing through the water using various strokes like freestyle or butterfly?
items.explanation: Competitive swimmers race to complete a specific distance faster than their opponents.
